div.p: THE PERPETVAL CROSSE OR PASSION OF IESVS CHRIST From the first instant Of his INCARNATION, to the last of his life set forth In fourtie pictures for the greater profite of soules.

figure.figDesc: Maltese cross

div.p: Printed at Antvverp By Cornelius Woons, dvvelling at the signe of the golden Starie, 1649.

div.head: The perpetual Crosse of IESVS CHRIST, both interiour, and exteriour, from the first instant of his Incarnation, to the very last of his Life.
div.p: THere are many of opinion that Christ onely suffered in the time of his Passion and vvas Crucified but those three hovvers that he hung upon the Crosse: vvhereas it is most certaine he vvas fastned thereunto, and lived in continuall sufferance the three and thirty vvhole yeares of his life, vvhich, devided into dayes, make at least tvvelve thousand and fifty, into hovvres tvvo hundred, eight'y nine thousand, tvvo hundred, seventy tvvo.

This assertion Cardinal Lugo shevves clearely out of scripture, a'nd holy fathers. CHRIST (Sayth he) vvas not onely in torments and sorrovv the tyme of his bitter Passion but during the vvhole course of his life. He did not onely greive at the death of Lazarus, and sight of Ierusalem; at both vvhich tymes he is saied to have vvept, but
he felt the like sorrow all the tyme our sins, and his ovvne Passion vvere represented to his minde, vvhich was continually, according to the holy Psalmist: Psal. 37. Quon • am ego in flagella paratus sum, et dolor meus in conspectu meo semper. Because I am ready for strypes and my greife is alvvaies in my sight. vvhich wordes are spoken of our B, Saviour, as S. Chrysostome, S. Austine, S. Ierome, and S. Gregory doe affirme: to omit innumerable other occasions of suffering vvhich he had according to those other vvords of the Psalmist. Psal. 87. Pauper sum ego, & in laboribns a iuuentute mea I am poore and in labours from my youth. Which vvordes are likevvise interpreted of our B. Saviour by S. Ierome, S. Austine, Euthymius and others. Thus Cardinal Lugo.

Cardinal Bellarmine agrees vvith Lugo in the same point; for, commenting upon the 87. Psalm. thus he writes: To the end vvee may not thinke CHRISTS Passion was onely three hovvers or at most, one vvhole day the Holy Ghoste doth heere declare unto us that he was never vvithout his sufferings: for besides his most bitter death, vvhich vvas allvvaies before his minde, he
vvas in continual Labours and misery his vvhole life long. Thus Bellarmine.
Hence vvee conclude that our B. Saviour vvas neuer vvithout his Crosse, both outvvard and invvard; and especially this latter, for the tovve reasons above mentioned by Card. Lugo.

There are divers other learned authours of the same opinion as Lessius De Perfect div 〈…〉 l. 12. c. 17. n. n. 133. Io. Eusebius Nierembergius. l. 2. c. 5. de Adoratione in spiritu & veritate. Io. Lorinus. Ps. 37. v. 18. Corn. à Lapide. Math. 26. v. 37. Balthasar Corderius. Ps. 87. v. 16. Anton. de Gaudier de natura & statib. Perfectionis▪ de Instrumentis. sect. 12. c. 5. Franciscus Arias. de Imitatione Christi. p. 3. c. 22. Tr. 1. Ioannes Baptista Sainctlure, De cognitione & amore Dei, lib. 1. cap. 11. sect. 1. Gabriel Vasques, Tom. 1. in. 3. p. q. 18. ab Disp. 73. c. 4. n, 28. R. P. Vincentius Carrafa Soc. JESV Praep. Generalis sub nomine Aloysij Siderei. De via caeli. c. 6. §. 9.

I content my selfe, at present, vvith the authority of these twelve learned vvriters all of them being of our least Society, and meddle not vvith men of other Orders▪
vvhoe are very many, both learned and grave, of the same opinion.

div.head: The manner and fashon of using the pictures of this little booke.
div.p: COnsider in every mystery some one, or more, of follovving circumstances.
1. Whoe is that suffers? God of an infinire Maiesty.
2. What it is that he suffers? A paine, vvhich is much augmented by the internal afflicton of his minde, that continually accompanies it.
3. For vvhome doth he suffer? For me that am a vile sinner.
4. Why? To comfort help and save me.
5. In what place? In that vvhere he findes gratest maitter of patience.
6. At vvhat tyme? At that vvhich is most inconvenient to himselfe, and most agreable to me.
7. From vvhome? From those very persons for vvhose sake he suffers.
8. After vvhat manner? After such an one as if neede vvere, he vvould suffer a hundred thousand times more for vs.

div.head: Afterwardes demand these twoe questions of thy selfe.
div.p: 1. WHat hetherto you have done for him? hardly any thing, but insteed of good a vvorld of iniquity.
2. What vvill you doe hence forvvard? thi • very day I vvill doe such, and such a good vvorke, and suffer such, and such a Crosse, for his sake.

Besides it vvill not be amisse to exercise some one of these acts follovving, vvhich maisters of spirit are vvont ordinarily to bring. 1. of Compassion. 2, of Gratitude. 3. Of Contrition. 4. Of admiration. 5. of Love. 6. of Confidence. 7, Of Imitation.

div.head: De Picturis.
div.p:
QVod legentibus scriptura, hoc idiotis praestat pictura cernentibus. Quia in istâ etiam ignorantes vident quod sequi debeant: in istâ legunt, qui literas nesciunt. Vnde & praecipuè gentibus pro lectione pictura est. Greg. Mag. l. 9. ep. 9. ad Serenū
Massil. A picture to the ignorant is like a booke to the learned. For the ignorant se • therein vvhat they are to practice; and those reade in it that knovv not theyr letters. Wherefore a picture serues the gentil • forl a lesson.

Triplex fuit causa institutionis imaginum in Ecclesiâ. Primò, ad instructionem laicorum quibus imagines exhibentur loco librorum. Secundò, vt Incarnation is Mysterium, & Sanctorum exempla nobis frequentius, & presentius affigerentur. Tertiò, ad excitandum devotionis affectum, qui magis ex visis, quam auditis causatur. Rob. Holcotius in libr. sapient. lect. 157.

For three respects the use of pictures vvas instituted in the Holy Church First to instruct the ignorant. Secondly, to imprint the mystery of the incarnation, and the example of saintes, more lively in our mindes. Thirdly, to stir us up to greater devotion, vvhich is done better by the obiect of our eyes then our eares.

div.head: The most Illustrious Lord Archbishop of Mechline grants 40. daies pardon to all that shal say this prayer once a day for thanck giuing, and increase of the honour of the continual Crosse of IESVS CHRIST.

p.hi: O IESVS crucified, let all men know the and love the it is the onely thing I desire. This doe I aske by the Crosse which thou modest choice of from alle eternity, and onderwent in thy Nativity, in thy Circumcision, at thy Oblation in the Temple, in thy Elight to Egypt, in the Leauing thy Parents, in thy Labouring with thy hands, in the death of S. Ioseph, in thy Temptations, in thy VVearines at the fountaine▪ in thy Ignominies from the Iewes, in the death of S. Iohn Baptist, in theyr Stoning the, in theyr offering to throw the downe from the mountayne. • aske the same likewise by all that thou sufferedst at the taking thy last leave of thy B. Mother, at the Table with Iudas, in the Garden, at his trecherous Kisse, at the Torrent of Cedron, in the House of Annas, Caiphas, Pilate, Herod, at the Pillar, at thy Crowning with thornes, at thy being shewen to the people, at thy Carrying the Crosse, at thy first fall vnder it, at thy meeting the same time thy B. Mother, Simon Cyraeneus, the devout Veronica, at thy second fall under the Crosse, at thy meeting the daughters of Ierusalem, at thy last fall under the Crosse, at the plucking of thy garmēt and drinking gall, at thy Crucifixcion on the ground, at thy Hanghing upon the Crosse, at thy taking downe from thence into the armes of thy most afflicted Mother, finally, at thy Burial and laying the in the Sepulchre. Againe and againe by all these Crosses doe I beg of the most sweete IESVS, that all men may know and love the, and it is the onely thing I desire. Amen.

div.p: The same P • elate grants like vvise 40. daies pardon to all that for the space of, Paters and s. Aves. shall meditate upon any one of these mysteries, or say s. Pater and Aves in honour of it.
div.closer: To the greater glorie of Christ ever Crucifie.
